title.narrative: SOM_Somalia, Somaliland, and Puntland Joint Response (SSP JR)

description.narrative: Rapid action is urgently needed to scale up the drought response in these regions in order to safeguard livelihoods and prevent further erosion of household’s nutrition and food security. The proposed activities closely align with the Call for Aid and 2016 HRP by focusing on the provision of immediate emergency life-saving and life-sustaining assistance to the most vulnerable, and restoring and strengthening livelihoods to build resilience to recurrent shocks in El Niño-affected regions. As stated in the Call for Aid, priority is to provide cash to save lives and enable recovery of livelihoods for pastoralists and agro-pastoralists through provision of unconditional cash transfers for vulnerable households, cash for work to rebuild essential infrastructure as well as livestock treatment. This is critical for improving household purchasing power to enable repayment of food credit, access to diversified food from local markets, reducing negative coping mechanisms while improving livestock production through disease control. The proposed locations, objectives and activities for this project are in line with the Call for Aid priorities.

Somalia HRP FSL Objective 1: Improve household immediate access to food through provision of unconditional transfer depending on the severity of food insecurity as per IPC classification, vulnerability and seasonality of the livelihoods Result 1.1 300 households have sufficient resources to meet household food needs Result 1.2 Improved water holding capacity of community water catchments for livestock production through Cash for Work for 400 households Somalia HRP FSL Objective 2: Increase productive capacity of rural and urban livelihoods through provision seasonally-appropriate and livelihood-specific inputs Result 2.1 Improved livestock health and productivity
The project targets 1,700 drought-affected pastoralists households in Dangoroyo (Nugal region) and Banderbeyla (Bari region) which have been deemed some of the most-affected by the drought.

title.narrative: Number of HH benefitting from C4W

comment.narrative: 400 households (HHs) (Ceel Buh 150 HH's, Ussgure 150 HH's and Baq Baq 100 HH's) in three villages were verified and registered for cash for work activities during the reporting period. 122 (31%) females and 278 (69%) males were targeted in cash for work activities. The cash for work activities were conducted in October and November 2016.The duration lasted for 48 days (24 days per month). Beneficiaries worked for six days and six hours per day each week excluding Fridays. A total of 1,615 children were reached through the cash for work component of the project. (920 persons between the ages of 5-17 years of age and 695 under five children).

Three unconditional cash transfers were distributed to 300 HH's in five drought affected communities under Banderbayla and Dangoroyo districts in August, September and November 2016. Each household received USD 140 per month to cover food and non-food item needs. A total of 1,384 children were reached under the unconditional cash grant component (879 persons between the ages of 5-17 years of age and 505 under five children).
